answers.a: Yes—sulfuric acid (H2SO4) is a very strong, diprotic mineral acid in water; its first proton dissociates completely (the second is weaker), and it is highly corrosive.

answers.q: what is sulfuric acid used for
answers.a: As the food additive E513, it’s used to control pH and as a processing aid in sugar refining and starch hydrolysis; more broadly it’s used in fertilizer production, chemical manufacturing, and lead-acid batteries.

answers.q: is h2so4 an acid or base
answers.a: An acid—specifically a strong, diprotic mineral acid.

answers.q: is sulfuric acid a strong acid
answers.a: Yes; it is considered a strong acid in water, with the first dissociation essentially complete.

answers.q: what does h2so4 do in a reaction
answers.a: It donates protons (H+) to lower pH and neutralize bases, forming sulfate salts; at high concentration it also acts as a dehydrating agent and acid catalyst (e.g., for esterification or hydrolysis).
